title: What will be the percentage change in average UK house prices over the 12-month period to September 2019?
preds: July is officially 232.7, which is +0.4% compared to Sept 2018.
This figure is literally published by the UK so we already know what will be reported .... what am I missing? Why are people still predicting even probabilities?
July in at 232,710, slightly up from 231,304 in Sept. 2018.

Official data hasn't been updated since June but third party data suggest a stagnation since June [1,2] When considered alongside my previous analysis [3] this suggests that the fourth bucket is nearly impossible. By my estimates based on the numbers reported in [1,2], September comes it at -0.5%. Reducing it from 30%. Also increasing the second bucket from 12%. [1] https://www.theguardian.com/money/2019/aug/30/brexit-housing-market-august-prices-nationwide
[2] https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-eu-housing/brexit-jitters-cause-rare-september-fall-in-uk-house-prices-rightmove-idUKKBN1W00VL
[3] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/894176

We're at 0.9% as of June 2019. An increase is unlikely as there's  general stalling of property market. London is falling starkly, but some areas have retained momentum which keeps us at low increase figures. However The London effect historically radiates out over time - making the prognosis poor for the rest of the Uk despite inherent momentum up until now. Brexit and over-valuation of flats and high end properties have affected London - but Provinces tend to be less affected by international matters and over hyped development aimed at international buyers. This would suggest that rest of Uk may stall and perhaps fall a little in areas but will not pull the average down too sharply.
Another negative indicator would be that the summer the  construction purchasing managers’ index has suffered it's worst drop since 2009.... this is an index of how construction industry is purchasing and developing. A significant drop here means new development has slowed sharply - usually a result of not being able to 'shift' already completed projects and maintain cash flow.
UK house prices will not be affected so much by Brexit, a global recession would be more of an issue.
Recession is coming.  Only can see positive growth is if data lags the behavior set to be brought on when the recession hits
I'm guessing around 0.5% overall and not much chance of it moving too far away from this.
Narrowing forecast as less time for something dramatic to happen.
major economic shift will be Brexit which will have an october deadline, one way or another. i suspect that consumer behaviour will not shift until more news on brexit comes.

June 2019 data (https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/uk-house-price-index-summary-june-2019/uk-house-price-index-summary-june-2019) shows an annual increase of 0.9%. It's quite difficult to expect major changes to that just in couple of months.
Brexit is having major influence in economic growth and housing.

Housing has already been impacted by the lack of resolution regarding Brexit.  However, with confirmation of a no deal exit or having to go back to another referendum, there is still uncertainty that will continue to dampen housing values.  A larger uncertainty is the potential for a global recession which would compound the negative impact on the British housing market.

Given that Brexit is the phenomenon  most likely to cause significant fall, and we will not know what is happening there by the end of September, It is unlikely that there will be either a significant collapse in prices or a substantial positive improvement.

Stagnation stagnation stagnation........ London prices overinflated and falling already to a a degree....although this does affect the higher priced Offerings usually fed upon by foreign investors the London effect is still likely to ripple outwards.
I think the hype around Brexit has already happened. The markets have already mostly adjusted.
It all depends on Brexit but the economy is fundamentally OK.

I do not have a lot of information about this topic, the following ideas are mostly conjectures. The UK will remain a lucrative housing market, as EU citizens were not the ones driving up prices. With the weak pound, prices are likely to increase.

Not enough houses to go around
Brexit is not a game changer for the housing market in UK.
Wording on this question and answers is poor. I think they’ll fall at least 3%.

Since the EU Referendum in 2016, indeed the greatest nodal point in the UK socioeconomic context since the financial crisis of 2008, the trend of the 'Annual house price rates of change' has been overall downward and with no great fluctuations.
Brexit remains an uncertainty but no major breakthrough has taken place since Nov 2018 (up to when the House Price Index data is available on the ONS website) nor a major change is expected in the few weeks that we have before end of Sep 2019 that would drastically alter the 12 month period figure anyway. Just the pound being weak might be a factor in favour of the house market.
Simple linear regression of rolling 12-month period prices by month since the EU Referendum forecasts a figure of +1.55% for Sep 2019. The same calculation done using an exponential smoothing algorithm gives +1.62% (albeit 90% confidence intervals range from -0.1% to +3.3%).
Therefore, my bet for between 1% and 3% as the most likely scenario.

Housing prices seem to have weakened over the past few months, with UK mortgage lenders Nationwide reporting July prices up 0.3% [1] and Halifax reporting prices down 0.2% [2].  The most recent UK House Price Index through May 2019)  indicates prices up 0.9%, continuing the gradual slowing over the past few years [3].  I now expect that generally flat housing prices (+/- 1%) is the most likely outcome, with a number just over 1% next likely.  I've left a small chance that prices could decline ahead of a possible (if not likely) hard Brexit at the end of October.   Thanks also to @Emil for his helpful analysis based on the Nationwide numbers [4]. [1] https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-houseprices-nationwide/uk-house-prices-stay-sluggish-as-brexit-drags-on-market-nationwide-idUKKCN1UQ0L2
[2] https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-economy-houseprices/uk-house-prices-unexpectedly-fall-in-july-halifax-idUKKCN1UX0Q3
[3] https://www.ons.gov.uk/economy/inflationandpriceindices/bulletins/housepriceindex/june2019
[4] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/894176
Actual June numbers are slightly lower than what I estimated based on third party data. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/894176  Raising the two lower buckets by 2 % points each.

House price growth has remained relatively stable over the last 18 months, but the number of sales has continued to declined. Mortgage completions are also relatively stable, and the lack of available housing stock continues to ensure that prices remain on an relatively upward trajectory. The July Halifax Price index was showing a +4.1% annualised growth rate. Given that it takes approx 3-4 months for a transaction to complete, the changing political climate would have little effect on price inflation for the Sept figures, as these transactions would have already been near completion. But given that the London and SE markets continue to be depressed, and they drive so much of the total UK market, I think that we are looking at an annualised growth rate of around the 3.5% - 3.8% 
https://static.halifax.co.uk/assets/pdf/mortgages/pdf/July-2019-Halifax-House-Price-Index.pdf

UK hasn't updated its numbers since May but Reuters reports prices grew 0.5% in June and 0.3% in July [1]. That would put the July number at 229.4 * 1.005 * 1.003 = 231.2. Sept 2018 was 231.7, so we are currently at a change of -0.2% according to this analysis with 2 months to go.  To break into the fourth bucket we'd need monthly growth of 0.5% in August and September. To be in the second bucket we'd need a monthly contraction of 0.5% in August and September. This is historically very rare. [2] Growth rates below -0.5% have been seen 8 times since January 2010. To get two consecutive months of such low growth rates would be even less likely. [1] https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-houseprices-nationwide/uk-house-prices-stay-sluggish-as-brexit-drags-on-market-nationwide-idUKKCN1UQ0L2
[2] http://landregistry.data.gov.uk/app/ukhpi/browse?from=2000-01-01&location=http%3A%2F%2Flandregistry.data.gov.uk%2Fid%2Fregion%2Funited-kingdom&to=2019-12-01

Its figures indicated commercial property investment activity in greater London was down by 31% year-on-year, while investment in markets outside London fell 33%'. https://www.google.com/amp/s/amp.theguardian.com/business/2019/aug/08/uk-housing-market-at-its-weakest-point-in-a-decade-brexit-says-savills

Quick starting forecast based on annual change in average house price in the United Kingdom HPI. Taken monthly values for annual change between Sep 2018 and Mar 2019. Ranges between 1.046% (Feb 2019) and 3.028% (Sep 2018). Possible baseline = Mar 2019 annual change of 1.425% Will update forecast later when investigate further. Source: https://www.gov.uk/government/statistical-data-sets/uk-house-price-index-data-downloads-march-2019

(A much less sophisticated approach than Emil elsewhere): Generally tightening ranges after (properly) consulting the data, recent handy sources are the Land registry page [1] or the May 2019 report [2]. May 2019's (3 months out) figure is +1.2%, continuing a gradual downward trend. For the ranges in the question: < -3%: Looks very unlikely as you'd need to drop by -4.3% in 3 months. Although the track record does show very fast swings, these are pretty rare and correlate with wider indicators (e.g. the last one with the financial crisis to which housing was highly exposed) which aren't observed here. Also, the indicator very rarely strays negative. -3% to -1%: This still looks unlikely for similar reasons (HPI is rarely negative, and drops of 2.3%/3months would be off the fairly autocorrelated trends), but not incredible. -1% to 1%: I place the bulk of my credence here firstly predicting the gradual decline will continue, and 0.2% in 3 months is very plausible. Also, although (I understand) housing a defensive investment, I'd guess political instability about Brexit would probably push in the downwards direction (although not so dramatically to go below -1%). 1 to 3%: My next most plausible option, as although close to the threshold the trend may reverse or have jitters, but again unlikely to surge up the 1.9% to exit the range. >3%: Similar to <-3%, but fractionally more plausible as less distance to go, HPI generally positive, etc. etc. One more thing: when you look at the Nov 2018 report, you see a value of 2.8% [3]. However, if you consult more recent reports, they give the figure for Nov 2018 as 2.6% [1] [2]. I haven't sleuthed carefully enough to understand why this is the case (revising estimates for greater accuracy?), but insofar as this suggests noise from the ground truth, it would point to widening credence across the ranges, especially as the current value is very close a cutpoint. [1] http://landregistry.data.gov.uk/app/ukhpi
[2] https://www.ons.gov.uk/economy/inflationandpriceindices/bulletins/housepriceindex/may2019
[3] https://www.ons.gov.uk/economy/inflationandpriceindices/bulletins/housepriceindex/november2018#uk-annual-growth-rate-increases-in-november

UPD4: May 229,400 now within the interval 
UPD3: Apr 2019 229,00 edging towards within -1% to 1% interval 
UPD2: Mar 2019 227,000 so still quite a bit to get to Sep 2018 
UPD: Feb 2019 226,234 more like going down In September 2018 the average price of a house in the UK was 231,787. The problem is that this number is hard to beat given that with the seasonal changes removed by ONS in January 2019 the average price was 228,147. This technically already 1.3 lower than in September 2018. That means the prices need to go up from 228,147 in Feb 2019 to 238,740 in September 2019 to get into "more than 3%" interval. Tough luck. 
However, the employment figures are still good and increase in minimum wage from April (typically for young / first time buyers' spouse) may bring even more first time buyers to the regional and cheaper than 230K market. Therefore, there is still a good chance to achieve slightly above 1% growth, e.g. ca. 234K average price in September 2019. First time buyers tend to overpay so there is a good chance for increase as the entire baseline will move a bit. 
The issue is London which has substantial weight on average prices. The recent witch hunt of foreign-money-laundering activities may have some negative effect and may cool off the London market even further. Still a 60 million mansion is negligible on grand scale of things since there were 100.000 seasonally adjusted property transactions in February 2019 at average price of 228,000. This brings us to £22.8 billion worth of houses changing hands every month or 12.5 % of GDP (UK GDP 511.5 billion in Q4 2018 or roughly 170 bn a month). Four mansions at 50 Mio will pull the average by 1% easy though.

May data came in at: 229.431. As a reminder, Sept 2018 was 231.7, therefore we are currently at -1%. This also represents a 1.2% increase on May 2018. The more meaningful number of the two is the latter. May is typically lower than September and we'd therefore expect growth from here. One disconfirming fact is that the growth from April to May this year was more tepid than it usually is. Latest results from Monte Carlo model: 4, 17, 34, 30, 15 (with rounding). I have adjusted them for economist expectations slightly as discussed previously.

Conducting a linear regression on the data from June 2018 to April 2019 (from http://landregistry.data.gov.uk/app/ukhpi/) and using residuals to estimate the variance gives 0.4 +/- 0.3 %. I arbitrarily double error to account for model uncertainty, assume a normal distribution to calculate the odds, and hedge the tails at 1% in case of some black swan event.
I thought about it and this is what I think based on a uniform uninformed prior.
Brexit uncertainty, and a new recession being due, will continue to suppress house prices.
Slightly less than government inflation target. Affected by brexit keeping prices low.

Pretty much just a technical analysis - particularly looking since 2012. Housing prices are interesting in that they're not driven by professionals (like equity markets), but punters. As such, most non-outlier shocks are equalled out - e.g. changes in government, macro/micro economic trends, media noise. I would love to do a bit more analysis, but this is basically just looking at short/mid/long term trends in the data, frequency of deltas big enough to move between each bracket, and a bit of eyeballing. Happy to share the (messy) sheet with anyone interested. For reference, my actual prediction for the the final September number is 0.6

Outside View: As described previously [1], I use base rates in the form of monthly price changes to build a distribution from which I create Random Walk projections (10,000 of them) and tabulate final frequencies. Since last forecast, the price has fallen to 226k GBP (latest data available is for February). The September 2018 price was 231.7k GBP.  Model results: 10, 20, 26, 24, 20 Inside view: "British economists expect house prices to grow by 1.8% this year, according to the latest consensus forecasts collected by the Treasury. The Office for Budget Responsibility, which provides independent forecasts for the government, predicts house price inflation of 0.8% in 2019." [2] Applying either a 1.8% or 0.8% annual growth (and adjusting by 3/4 to account for expected price increase until September), I get a Sept 2019 price of 233.9k or 232k. Relative to Sept 2018, this equates to 0.9% growth or 0.2% growth respectively.  [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/821760
[2] https://www.theguardian.com/money/2019/apr/05/house-prices-hold-up-better-than-forecast-amid-brexit-chaos HT @nigster

Looking at the data in the link in the question, house prices have been in decline since the June 2016 Brexit vote.  At a current (January 2019) 1.7% annual increase, the trendline points to about a 0 to slightly negative amount by September.  That's if everything continues as it is today.  If credit tightens (unlikely) or a hard Brexit occurs, that would create lower buyer confidence.  Both of these items seldom has an immediate effect on house prices, as it takes 3-6 months for the lower demand to cause sellers to lower their expectations.  So. mostly this depends on when Brexit is finalized, less on what the solution turns out to be.

Uk House price index (Land Registry) -1.57% from 30/09/18 to 31/1/19 (NSA). Nationwide SA figures (MoM) imply that over this period it was -0.2%, and that from 30/09/18 to 31/03/19 prices are flat.  Markit/ Halifax SA figures (MoM) imply that over the first period it was -1.08%, 30/09/2018 to 31/03/19 prices are +3.18% (buoyed by a huge 6% increase MoM SA figure of 6% for Feb).  Using these final 2 series and simply averaging, I get that we are currently at c.+1.6% SA. This informs my upward bias, however volatility informs the spread of probabilities.  What could harm my prediction?
Rising rates faster than expectations
General market downturns (leading to negative wealth effects and more reluctance to move house)
The B word.

I think @Emil 's Monte Carlo model is a good place to start when thinking about scenarios where 'the future is like the past' https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/821760
However, from the development of housing prices at http://landregistry.data.gov.uk/app/ukhpi/browse?from=1995-01-01&location=http%3A%2F%2Flandregistry.data.gov.uk%2Fid%2Fregion%2Funited-kingdom&to=2018-12-01 we also see a massive dip during the financial crisis of 2008/2009. I think this crisis scenario needs to be taken into account when considering a no deal Brexit scenario. The other variable here is whether there will be a delay of Brexit, which I consider quite likely in this forecast: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/823066 So I consider these scenarios where the Monte Carlo model assumption that the future is like the past holds (bucket probabilities for all scenarios: 0, 10, 15, 45, 30) :
Deal Brexit on 29th March: 9% probability
Deal Brexit between 29th March and 30th September 2019: 60% probability
Brexit after 30th September 2019: 13% probability If there is a no deal Brexit on 29th March (9% probability), I would assume that a future that is like the worst of the recent past becomes more likely (bucket probabilities 15, 20, 40, 20, 5). In this case a potential decrease in prices also has the most time to materialize. If there is a no deal Brexit between 29th March and 30th September (9% probability), I would also assume that a future that is like the worst of the recent past becomes more likely, but as the time between the crisis trigger and the close date of the question is shorter, I adjust my bucket probabilities for this scenario so that the bucket including 0% change gets the highest probability, with a more pessimistic overall outlook. Bucket probabilities: 8, 12, 67, 12, 1 Multiplying the scenario probabilities with the bucket probabilities and summing up gives me the forecast.

Even if we have greater clarity on brexit and no-deal is avoided, hard to see meaningful appreciation in house prices against a backdrop of slowing investment, a slower economy, higher stamp duty, reduced BTL allowance etc. ie more headwinds that tailwinds.

What's putting an anchor on pricing at the moment is uncertainty - yes, including Brexit but also associated headlines about job losses etc - and the very limited supply of properties coming to market. Since 3 weeks ago, supply in my area (outer south east)  has started to increase markedly and there is a lot more market activity according to agents. The puff never went out of some areas, like Cambridge, but London has been weighed down by exit of foreign money and buy to let (10% or so centrally, local evidence for both).  IF there is no Brexit or a very long, slow one, activity will bounce because uncertainty will be reduced.  There is a constant low level of sales due to probate, divorce, unavoidable job moves etc., but also factor in a significant cost of moving in the south because of stamp duty, and CGT in some cases. But everyone's been holding their breath for 2-3 years so there is pent-up demand. I see static prices in first half of the year (using prices for 2018 which may have been discounted by 5% already) but increases in the second half as the market unfreezes. I also see the south moving faster than the north.

Earlier I talked about my Monte Carlo model [1]. Here I introduce an alternative way of looking at it.  Year-on-year growth rate is autocorrelated (correlated with past versions of itself), not surprisingly, and it has been trending downward for at least the past two years. I estimated the downward rate and extrapolated it forward.  Result: 1.1% for YoY growth in September 2018 (if I use data from the past 12 months) and 1.8% (if I use data from the past 24 months).  Additionally, with regard to the Inside View @nigster makes a good point that Brexit hasn't had a visible impact on the house price index. Indeed, one would expect that the short term effects of Brexit are mostly reflected in financial and currency markets, while markets like housing are more stable. It is generally the case that the former are more volatile and the latter is more stable. That is why real estate is considered a defensive investment after all. This is not to say that Brexit won't have a long-term effect on housing (through changes in interest rates or immigration) but those shouldn't have as strong of an impact in the shorter timeframe of this question. Therefore, I am limiting the probabilities of the lower buckets.

Buckets here seem pretty narrow for me .. Based on historic data from 2006 percentage change was lower than -3% or higher than 3% 70% of the time.  And only around 10% for each other bucket. However Brexit uncertainity makes over 3% bucket which represented 60% of historic data much less probable than it look  from historic data. For now each of bucket seem almost equally possible for me and I am going to update depending on Brexit outcome and next months reports.

Outside view: My Monte Carlo model uses data [2] since 2000 to project prices out to September 2019 10,000 times, compares the resulting Sept 2019 to Sept 2018 and tabulates frequencies. Results: 2, 6, 14, 20, 59 (rounded).  It seems quite bullish relative to GJO so far and relative to the range of the question. But the model reflects an important fact: historically, house prices have gone up more often than down or sideways. On average, they have grown 0.4%/mo since 2000. If you just project using that average growth rate from the November number, you'd get an annual growth of 3.5% from Sept 2018 to Sept 2019.  Additionally, the model is helpful in providing a sense for the range of uncertainty we can expect based on the historical variance in prices. Inside view: Dependent on Brexit, interests rates, ability of consumers to take out loans, and immigration rates among others. I will address these in future posts. For now, I am tempering the bullishness of the model. I am accounting for the diverse views that see a slow down in the market [1]  [1] https://www.bbc.com/news/business-46543252
[2] http://landregistry.data.gov.uk/app/ukhpi/browse?from=2000-01-01&location=http%3A%2F%2Flandregistry.data.gov.uk%2Fid%2Fregion%2Funited-kingdom&to=2018-12-01
